Groggy - Graph Language Interface
  • API Reference
  • groggy module
  • View page source

groggy module

Groggy - A Graph Language Engine for dynamic graphs and versioned state High-performance graph manipulation library with Rust backend

class groggy.ColumnarStore

Bases: object

Columnar storage for graph attributes with bitmap indexing

get_stats()

Get storage statistics

class groggy.FastGraph(directed)

Bases: object

FastGraph struct with hybrid/columnar storage (MAIN IMPLEMENTATION)

add_edge(source, target, attributes=None)

Add a single edge with optional attributes

add_edges(edges_data)

Add multiple edges in batch

add_node(node_id, attributes=None)

Add a single node with optional attributes

add_nodes(nodes_data)

Add multiple nodes in batch

edge_count()

Get edge count

filter_edges_by_attributes(filters)

Filter edges by attribute dictionary - optimized for exact matches

filter_edges_by_numeric_comparison(attr_name, operator, value)

Filter edges by numeric comparison - optimized for performance

filter_edges_by_string_comparison(attr_name, operator, value)

Filter edges by string comparison - optimized for performance

filter_nodes_by_attributes(filters)

Filter nodes by attribute dictionary - optimized for exact matches

filter_nodes_by_numeric_comparison(attr_name, operator, value)

Filter nodes by numeric comparison - optimized for performance

filter_nodes_by_string_comparison(attr_name, operator, value)

Filter nodes by string comparison - optimized for performance

get_all_neighbors(node_id)

Get all neighbors of a node (both incoming and outgoing)

get_edge_attributes(source, target)

Get edge attributes - retrieve from columnar store

get_edge_ids()

Get edge IDs

get_incoming_neighbors(node_id)

Get incoming neighbors of a node (for directed graphs)

get_neighbors(node_id)

Get neighbors of a node (for directed graphs, returns only outgoing neighbors)

get_node_attributes(node_id)

Get node attributes - retrieve from columnar store

get_node_ids()

Get all node IDs

get_outgoing_neighbors(node_id)

Get outgoing neighbors of a node (for directed graphs)

has_edge(source, target)

Check if edge exists

has_node(node_id)

Check if node exists

is_directed()

Check if the graph is directed

node_count()

Get node count

remove_edge(source, target)

Remove an edge

remove_edges(edge_pairs)

Remove multiple edges

remove_node(node_id)

Remove a node and all its edges

remove_nodes(node_ids)

Remove multiple nodes

set_edge_attribute(source, target, attribute, value)

Set a single edge attribute

set_edge_attributes(source, target, attributes)

Set multiple edge attributes at once

set_edges_attributes_batch(edge_attrs)

Set batch edge attributes - efficiently set attributes for multiple edges

set_node_attribute(node_id, attribute, value)

Set a single node attribute

set_nodes_attributes_batch(node_attrs)

Set batch node attributes - efficiently set attributes for multiple nodes

class groggy.Graph(nodes=None, edges=None, graph_attributes=None, backend=None, max_auto_states: int = 10, directed: bool = True)[source]

Bases: StateMixin

High-level Graph interface with automatic Rust/Python backend selection

__init__(nodes=None, edges=None, graph_attributes=None, backend=None, max_auto_states: int = 10, directed: bool = True)[source]
add_edge(source: str | int, target: str | int, **attributes) → str[source]

Add an edge to the graph

add_edges(edges_data: List[Dict[str, Any]])[source]

Add multiple edges efficiently in a single operation

Parameters:

edges_data – List of edge dictionaries, each containing ‘source’, ‘target’ and optional attributes

Example

edges = [

{‘source’: ‘user_1’, ‘target’: ‘user_2’, ‘relationship’: ‘manages’}, {‘source’: ‘user_2’, ‘target’: ‘user_3’, ‘relationship’: ‘collaborates’}

] g.add_edges(edges)

add_node(node_id: str | int | None = None, **attributes) → str[source]

Add a node to the graph

add_nodes(nodes_data: List[Dict[str, Any]])[source]

Add multiple nodes efficiently in a single operation

Parameters:

nodes_data – List of node dictionaries, each containing ‘id’ and optional attributes

Example

nodes = [

{‘id’: ‘user_1’, ‘age’: 25, ‘role’: ‘engineer’}, {‘id’: ‘user_2’, ‘age’: 30, ‘role’: ‘manager’}

] g.add_nodes(nodes)

filter_edges(filter_func: Callable[[str, str | int, str | int, Dict[str, Any]], bool] | Dict[str, Any] | str = None, return_subgraph: bool = False, **kwargs) → List[str] | Subgraph[source]

Filter edges by lambda function, attribute values, string query, or keyword arguments

Parameters:

  • filter_func – Either a callable that takes (edge_id, source, target, attributes) and returns bool, a dictionary of attribute filters, or a string query like “weight > 0.5”

  • return_subgraph – If True, return a new Subgraph with filtered edges and connected nodes. If False, return a list of edge IDs (default)

  • **kwargs – Keyword arguments for attribute filtering (e.g., relationship=’friend’, weight=0.8)

Returns:

List of edge IDs that match the filter, or a new Subgraph instance if return_subgraph=True

Examples

# Function predicate filtered_ids = graph.filter_edges(lambda edge_id, src, tgt, attrs: attrs.get(‘weight’, 0) > 0.5)

# Dictionary predicate filtered_ids = graph.filter_edges({‘relationship’: ‘friend’, ‘active’: True})

# String query filtered_ids = graph.filter_edges(“weight > 0.5 and relationship == ‘colleague’”)

# Keyword arguments (most convenient) filtered_ids = graph.filter_edges(relationship=’friend’) filtered_ids = graph.filter_edges(relationship=’colleague’, weight=0.8)

# Return subgraph subgraph = graph.filter_edges(relationship=’friend’, return_subgraph=True)

filter_edges_by_attributes(filters: Dict[str, Any]) → List[str][source]

Legacy alias for filter_edges with attribute dictionary

filter_nodes(filter_func: Callable[[str | int, Dict[str, Any]], bool] | Dict[str, Any] | str = None, return_subgraph: bool = False, **kwargs) → List[str] | Subgraph[source]

Filter nodes by lambda function, attribute values, string query, or keyword arguments

Parameters:

  • filter_func – Either a callable that takes (node_id, attributes) and returns bool, a dictionary of attribute filters, or a string query like “role == ‘Manager’”

  • return_subgraph – If True, return a new Subgraph with filtered nodes and their edges. If False, return a list of node IDs (default)

  • **kwargs – Keyword arguments for attribute filtering (e.g., role=’engineer’, age=30)

Returns:

List of node IDs that match the filter, or a new Subgraph instance if return_subgraph=True

Examples

# Function predicate filtered_ids = graph.filter_nodes(lambda node_id, attrs: attrs.get(‘age’, 0) > 30)

# Dictionary predicate filtered_ids = graph.filter_nodes({‘role’: ‘Manager’, ‘department’: ‘Engineering’})

# String query filtered_ids = graph.filter_nodes(“role == ‘Manager’ and salary > 100000”)

# Keyword arguments (most convenient) filtered_ids = graph.filter_nodes(role=’engineer’) filtered_ids = graph.filter_nodes(role=’Manager’, department=’Engineering’)

# Return subgraph subgraph = graph.filter_nodes(role=’Manager’, return_subgraph=True)

filter_nodes_by_attributes(filters: Dict[str, Any]) → List[str][source]

Legacy alias for filter_nodes with attribute dictionary

property states

Get all states with their hashes (lazy-loaded view into backend)

subgraph(node_ids: List[str | int] = None, edge_ids: List[str] = None, include_edges: bool = True) → Subgraph[source]

Create a single subgraph from specified nodes or edges

Parameters:

  • node_ids – List of node IDs to include in the subgraph

  • edge_ids – List of edge IDs to include in the subgraph

  • include_edges – If True and node_ids provided, include edges between specified nodes

Returns:

Subgraph containing the specified nodes/edges

Examples

# Create subgraph from specific nodes sub = g.subgraph(node_ids=[‘alice’, ‘bob’, ‘charlie’])

# Create subgraph from specific edges (includes connected nodes) sub = g.subgraph(edge_ids=[‘alice->bob’, ‘bob->charlie’])

# Create subgraph from nodes without their edges sub = g.subgraph(node_ids=[‘alice’, ‘bob’], include_edges=False)

subgraphs(group_by: str | Dict[str, List[Any]] = None, **filters) → Dict[str, Subgraph][source]

Create multiple subgraphs grouped by attribute values

Parameters:

  • group_by – Either: - String: attribute name to group nodes by (like SQL GROUP BY) - Dict: mapping of group names to lists of attribute values

  • **filters – Additional filters as keyword arguments

Returns:

Dictionary mapping attribute values to Subgraph objects

Examples

# Group by single attribute (discovers unique values) subs = g.subgraphs(‘department’) # Returns {‘engineering’: subgraph, ‘design’: subgraph, …}

# Group by specific attribute values subs = g.subgraphs(role=[‘engineer’, ‘manager’]) # Returns {‘engineer’: subgraph, ‘manager’: subgraph}

# Group by custom mapping groups = {

‘technical’: [‘engineer’, ‘architect’], ‘leadership’: [‘manager’, ‘director’]

} subs = g.subgraphs(group_by={‘role’: groups}) # Returns {‘technical’: subgraph, ‘leadership’: subgraph}

# Multiple filters subs = g.subgraphs(‘department’, active=True, salary_min=50000)

# Access subgraphs by attribute value: designer_sub = subs[‘designer’] # Gets subgraph with filter_criteria=”role=designer”

update_edge(source: str | int, target: str | int, attributes: Dict[str, Any] | None = None, **kwargs)[source]

Update edge attributes with a user-friendly interface

Parameters:

  • source – Source node ID of the edge to update

  • target – Target node ID of the edge to update

  • attributes – Dictionary of attributes to set (optional)

  • **kwargs – Attributes as keyword arguments

Examples

g.update_edge(“alice”, “bob”, {“relationship”: “colleague”, “since”: 2020}) g.update_edge(“alice”, “bob”, relationship=”colleague”, since=2020) g.update_edge(“alice”, “bob”, {“relationship”: “colleague”}, since=2020) # Both work together

update_node(node_id: str | int, attributes: Dict[str, Any] | None = None, **kwargs)[source]

Update node attributes with a user-friendly interface

Parameters:

  • node_id – ID of the node to update

  • attributes – Dictionary of attributes to set (optional)

  • **kwargs – Attributes as keyword arguments

Examples

g.update_node(“alice”, {“age”: 31, “role”: “senior_engineer”}) g.update_node(“alice”, age=31, role=”senior_engineer”) g.update_node(“alice”, {“age”: 31}, role=”senior_engineer”) # Both work together

update_nodes(updates: Dict[str | int, Dict[str, Any]])[source]

Update multiple nodes efficiently in a single operation

Parameters:

updates – Dictionary mapping node IDs to their attribute updates

Example

updates = {

‘user_1’: {‘salary’: 80000, ‘role’: ‘senior_engineer’}, ‘user_2’: {‘salary’: 90000, ‘department’: ‘engineering’}

} g.update_nodes(updates)

class groggy.Subgraph(parent_graph: Graph | None = None, filter_criteria: str | None = None, metadata: Dict[str, Any] | None = None, **kwargs)[source]

Bases: Graph

A Subgraph is a Graph with additional metadata about its origin.

This is a simple extension of Graph that tracks: - The parent graph it was created from - The filter criteria used to create it - Any additional metadata

__init__(parent_graph: Graph | None = None, filter_criteria: str | None = None, metadata: Dict[str, Any] | None = None, **kwargs)[source]

Initialize a Subgraph.

Parameters:

  • parent_graph – The Graph this subgraph was created from

  • filter_criteria – The filter string/criteria used to create this subgraph

  • metadata – Additional metadata about this subgraph

  • **kwargs – Arguments passed to the parent Graph constructor

__repr__()[source]

String representation of the subgraph.

get_metadata() → Dict[str, Any][source]

Get all metadata about this subgraph.

groggy.create_random_graph(n_nodes: int = 10, edge_probability: float = 0.3, use_rust: bool | None = None) → Graph[source]

Create a random graph efficiently using vectorized operations

Get list of available backends.

groggy.get_current_backend()[source]

Get the currently selected backend.

groggy.set_backend(backend)[source]

Set the backend to use for new Graph instances.

Module Contents

The main Groggy module provides the primary interface for graph operations with a unified Rust-based backend.

Classes

Graph

High-level Graph interface with automatic Rust/Python backend selection

Functions

create_random_graph

Create a random graph efficiently using vectorized operations

Constants

groggy.__version__ = "0.2.0"

str(object=’’) -> str str(bytes_or_buffer[, encoding[, errors]]) -> str

Create a new string object from the given object. If encoding or errors is specified, then the object must expose a data buffer that will be decoded using the given encoding and error handler. Otherwise, returns the result of object.__str__() (if defined) or repr(object). encoding defaults to sys.getdefaultencoding(). errors defaults to ‘strict’.

Core Graph Interface

The unified Graph class provides high-performance operations through Rust backend:

filter_edges(filter_func: Callable[[str, str | int, str | int, Dict[str, Any]], bool] | Dict[str, Any] | str = None, return_subgraph: bool = False, **kwargs) → List[str] | Subgraph[source]

Filter edges by lambda function, attribute values, string query, or keyword arguments

Parameters:

  • filter_func – Either a callable that takes (edge_id, source, target, attributes) and returns bool, a dictionary of attribute filters, or a string query like “weight > 0.5”

  • return_subgraph – If True, return a new Subgraph with filtered edges and connected nodes. If False, return a list of edge IDs (default)

  • **kwargs – Keyword arguments for attribute filtering (e.g., relationship=’friend’, weight=0.8)

Returns:

List of edge IDs that match the filter, or a new Subgraph instance if return_subgraph=True

Examples

# Function predicate filtered_ids = graph.filter_edges(lambda edge_id, src, tgt, attrs: attrs.get(‘weight’, 0) > 0.5)

# Dictionary predicate filtered_ids = graph.filter_edges({‘relationship’: ‘friend’, ‘active’: True})

# String query filtered_ids = graph.filter_edges(“weight > 0.5 and relationship == ‘colleague’”)

# Keyword arguments (most convenient) filtered_ids = graph.filter_edges(relationship=’friend’) filtered_ids = graph.filter_edges(relationship=’colleague’, weight=0.8)

# Return subgraph subgraph = graph.filter_edges(relationship=’friend’, return_subgraph=True)

Filter nodes by lambda function, attribute values, string query, or keyword arguments

Parameters:

  • filter_func – Either a callable that takes (node_id, attributes) and returns bool, a dictionary of attribute filters, or a string query like “role == ‘Manager’”

  • return_subgraph – If True, return a new Subgraph with filtered nodes and their edges. If False, return a list of node IDs (default)

  • **kwargs – Keyword arguments for attribute filtering (e.g., role=’engineer’, age=30)

Returns:

List of node IDs that match the filter, or a new Subgraph instance if return_subgraph=True

# Function predicate filtered_ids = graph.filter_nodes(lambda node_id, attrs: attrs.get(‘age’, 0) > 30)

subgraph(node_ids: List[str | int] = None, edge_ids: List[str] = None, include_edges: bool = True) → Subgraph[source]

Create a single subgraph from specified nodes or edges

Parameters:

  • node_ids – List of node IDs to include in the subgraph

  • edge_ids – List of edge IDs to include in the subgraph

  • include_edges – If True and node_ids provided, include edges between specified nodes

Returns:

Subgraph containing the specified nodes/edges

Examples

# Create subgraph from specific nodes sub = g.subgraph(node_ids=[‘alice’, ‘bob’, ‘charlie’])

# Create subgraph from specific edges (includes connected nodes) sub = g.subgraph(edge_ids=[‘alice->bob’, ‘bob->charlie’])

# Create subgraph from nodes without their edges sub = g.subgraph(node_ids=[‘alice’, ‘bob’], include_edges=False)

subgraphs(group_by: str | Dict[str, List[Any]] = None, **filters) → Dict[str, Subgraph][source]

Create multiple subgraphs grouped by attribute values

Parameters:

  • group_by – Either: - String: attribute name to group nodes by (like SQL GROUP BY) - Dict: mapping of group names to lists of attribute values

  • **filters – Additional filters as keyword arguments

Returns:

Dictionary mapping attribute values to Subgraph objects

Examples

# Group by single attribute (discovers unique values) subs = g.subgraphs(‘department’) # Returns {‘engineering’: subgraph, ‘design’: subgraph, …}

# Group by specific attribute values subs = g.subgraphs(role=[‘engineer’, ‘manager’]) # Returns {‘engineer’: subgraph, ‘manager’: subgraph}

# Group by custom mapping groups = {

‘technical’: [‘engineer’, ‘architect’], ‘leadership’: [‘manager’, ‘director’]

} subs = g.subgraphs(group_by={‘role’: groups}) # Returns {‘technical’: subgraph, ‘leadership’: subgraph}

# Multiple filters subs = g.subgraphs(‘department’, active=True, salary_min=50000)

# Access subgraphs by attribute value: designer_sub = subs[‘designer’] # Gets subgraph with filter_criteria=”role=designer”

update_edge(source: str | int, target: str | int, attributes: Dict[str, Any] | None = None, **kwargs)[source]

Update edge attributes with a user-friendly interface

Parameters:

  • source – Source node ID of the edge to update

  • target – Target node ID of the edge to update

  • attributes – Dictionary of attributes to set (optional)

  • **kwargs – Attributes as keyword arguments

Examples

g.update_edge(“alice”, “bob”, {“relationship”: “colleague”, “since”: 2020}) g.update_edge(“alice”, “bob”, relationship=”colleague”, since=2020) g.update_edge(“alice”, “bob”, {“relationship”: “colleague”}, since=2020) # Both work together

update_node(node_id: str | int, attributes: Dict[str, Any] | None = None, **kwargs)[source]

Update node attributes with a user-friendly interface

Parameters:

  • node_id – ID of the node to update

  • attributes – Dictionary of attributes to set (optional)

  • **kwargs – Attributes as keyword arguments

Examples

g.update_node(“alice”, {“age”: 31, “role”: “senior_engineer”}) g.update_node(“alice”, age=31, role=”senior_engineer”) g.update_node(“alice”, {“age”: 31}, role=”senior_engineer”) # Both work together

update_nodes(updates: Dict[str | int, Dict[str, Any]])[source]

Update multiple nodes efficiently in a single operation

Parameters:

updates – Dictionary mapping node IDs to their attribute updates

Example

updates = {

‘user_1’: {‘salary’: 80000, ‘role’: ‘senior_engineer’}, ‘user_2’: {‘salary’: 90000, ‘department’: ‘engineering’}

} g.update_nodes(updates)

groggy.set_backend(backend)[source]

Set the backend to use for new Graph instances.

groggy.get_current_backend()[source]

Get the currently selected backend.

groggy.RUST_BACKEND_AVAILABLE = True

bool(x) -> bool

Returns True when the argument x is true, False otherwise. The builtins True and False are the only two instances of the class bool. The class bool is a subclass of the class int, and cannot be subclassed.
